message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infarction in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery suggests that the right occipital lobe is affected. This area is responsible for processing visual information from the left visual field, so a right-sided homonymous hemianopia is the most likely finding. None of the other options are associated with this specific location of infarction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the infarction in the posterior cerebral artery suggests that the most likely finding is right-sided homonymous hemianopia, which is a loss of vision in both eyes on the same side of the visual field. Left-sided gaze deviation and prosopagnosia are associated with lesions in other areas of the brain, while right-sided superior quadrantanopia suggests a lesion in the right occipital lobe, which is not consistent with the CT scan findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of decreased sensation in the right arm and leg along with a CT scan showing infarction in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery suggests a right-sided homonymous hemianopia. Gaze deviation and prosopagnosia are unlikely to be associated with this specific stroke, and superior quadrantanopia is typically associated with infarctions in the distribution of the middle cerebral artery.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The left posterior cerebral artery supplies blood to the visual cortex and occipital lobe, which means an acute infarction in its distribution will cause right-sided homonymous hemianopia. Left-sided gaze deviation may be caused by a lesion in the contralateral frontal eye field. Prosopagnosia is caused by lesions in the fusiform gyrus. Right-sided superior quadrantanopia may be caused by a lesion in the left optic tract or right occipital lobe.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The given symptoms suggest that the patient has had a stroke, specifically an acute infarction in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery. Damage to this artery can cause a right-sided homonymous hemianopia, which is the loss of the left half of the visual field in both eyes. Left-sided gaze deviation is not typical of this type of infarction. Prosopagnosia is the inability to recognize faces and is associated with damage to the fusiform gyrus, which is unlikely to be affected by this particular infarction. Right-sided superior quadrantanopia is associated with damage to the optic radiation, which is often supplied by the posterior cerebral artery, but would not cause the other symptoms mentioned in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and CT scan suggest an acute infarction in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery. This artery supplies the occipital lobe, which is responsible for vision, making right-sided homonymous hemianopia the most likely finding. Left-sided gaze deviation is a symptom of frontal lobe damage and prosopagnosia is associated with damage to the temporal lobe, while right-sided superior quadrantanopia is associated with damage to the optic radiations in the temporal lobe.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, specifically the decreased sensation on the right side, suggest a stroke in the left posterior cerebral artery. A stroke in this area commonly results in right-sided homonymous hemianopia, where a patient cannot see the visual field of the left side in both eyes. Left-sided gaze deviation suggests a stroke in the right hemisphere. Prosopagnosia suggests a stroke in the right occipitotemporal area. Right-sided superior quadrantanopia suggests a stroke in the left Meyer's loop.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The left posterior cerebral artery supplies the occipital lobe, which is responsible for vision. A lesion in this area would result in a homonymous hemianopia, which is defined as loss of vision in one half of the visual field in both eyes. Left-sided gaze deviation is more commonly seen in lesions involving the frontal lobe, prosopagnosia is associated with lesions in the temporal lobe, and right-sided superior quadrantanopia is associated with lesions in the right occipital lobe.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The left posterior cerebral artery supplies the occipital lobe, which is responsible for vision. Homonymous hemianopia is a common complication of an infarction in this area. None of the other options are associated with this area of the brain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a stroke in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery. This artery supplies the occipital lobe, which is responsible for visual processing. Therefore, right-sided homonymous hemianopia (loss of half of the visual field in both eyes) is the most likely finding. Left-sided gaze deviation and prosopagnosia are associated with lesions in other areas of the brain, while right-sided superior quadrantanopia would occur with a stroke in the distribution of the right posterior cerebral artery.
